CMultiXAppMsg Class Reference

List of all members.

Detailed Description

This base class contains all the logic for handling MultiX messages exchanged between MultiX based applications. It has the ability to format the message, save information about source, destination, flags, errors and other information regarding a message sent or delivered to a process or a session. Usually, this class is used in the receiving side of a message and in the completion functions of a send operation, the application cannot send a message based on this class. Most of its functions gives the programmer the ability to fetch information rather than modify it.

  FlagResponseRequired = 0x000004,
  FlagNotifyAll = 0x000007

Friends

class CMultiXProcess

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum CMultiXAppMsg::SendFlags

These flags are used in Send() or Reply() functions.

Enumerator:
FlagNotifyError  the Sender request to be notified on any error occured to the message being sent.
FlagNotifySuccess  The sender request to be notified on a successful send.
FlagResponseRequired  The sender requires the receiver of the message to explicitly reply to this message by means of Reply().
FlagNotifyAll  The sender requires to be notified in any case on the outcome of the message.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

CMultiXAppMsg::CMultiXAppMsg ( CMultiXProcess *  pProcess,
CMultiXMsg *  pMsg = NULL 
) [protected]

This constructor is called by the application or by a derived class. The caller must provide the Process that will own this message wethere it is for input or output. Every message object belongs to a CMultiXProcess derived object and is managed by this object. If a CMultiXMsg pointer is provided, MultiX will extract this msg and store relevant information in member fields of the new object, this is usually the case when a new message is received from a remote process.

Parameters:
pProcess The owner of the message.
pMsg The initializing msg.

bool CMultiXAppMsg::Reply ( MultiXError  Error = MultiXNoError,
TMultiXProcID  RoutedFrom = 0,
int  Flags = 0 
)

Send an empty reply with error only to the sender of this message.

Parameters:
Error error indication to the receiver, zero means no error.
RoutedFrom If there is a need to specify that the response is from another process.
Flags Flags to use for this Reply operation, see CMultiXAppMsg::SendFlags.

bool CMultiXAppMsg::Reply ( int32_t  MsgCode,
const void *  Data,
int32_t  DataSize,
int  Flags = 0,
int  Priority = 0,
uint32_t  Timeout = 0,
void *  Context = NULL,
TMultiXProcID  RoutedFrom = 0,
MultiXError  Error = MultiXNoError 
)

Send a data reply to the sender of this message.

Parameters:
MsgCode Message Code to use for this Reply operation, application defined.
Data A pointer to the binary data to send.
DataSize Size of the data to send.
Flags Flags to use for this send operation, see CMultiXAppMsg::SendFlags.
Priority Should be zero, for future use only.
Timeout How long should MultiX wait for this message to get to its destination. if it didn't arrive by this time, the message is consdired as failed. This parameter has meanning only if flags specify one of FlagNotifyError, FlagNotifySuccess or FlagResponseRequired. Timeout is specified in milliseconds.
Context some 32 bits value that the application passes. this value is saved and can be retrieved later in one of the message completetion virtual functions. see CMultiXAppMsg::SavedContext().
RoutedFrom If it is not zero, it is an indication to the remote process that this message is originated is originated in another process and not in the current one.
Error error indication to the receiver, application defined.
Returns:
true if MultiX successfully queued the message for transmition.

CMultiXBuffer &  MultiXBuf,
int  Flags = 0,
int  Priority = 0,

This parameter has meanning only if flags specify one of FlagNotifyError, FlagNotifySuccess or FlagResponseRequired. Timeout is specified in milliseconds.
Context some 32 bits value that the application passes. this value is saved and can be retrieved later in one of the message completetion virtual functions. see CMultiXAppMsg::SavedContext().
RoutedFrom If it is not zero, it is an indication to the remote process that this message is originated is originated in another process and not in the current one.

true if MultiX successfully queued the message for transmition.

This parameter has meanning only if flags specify one of FlagNotifyError, FlagNotifySuccess or FlagResponseRequired. Timeout is specified in milliseconds.

RoutedFrom If it is not zero, it is an indication to the remote process that this message is originated is originated in another process and not in the current one.
